children.subject: Just as a suggestion, you can always double major and get the best of both worlds

history.content:
EECS/CS for sure in AI/ML

---------------------

I wouldn't say for sure, I know several math majors doing interesting research in AI and looking at AI-related Ph.D. Programs

- you're right, but the numbers are far fewer. if OP is trying to maximize his chances then EECS/CS is the way to go with coursework/research in AI ML. You can look at department websites at other institutions, they most, if not all(?) prefer a EECS/CS background 

---------------------

(Garrett)

I think you're right that having a strong math background is looked upon favorably, but you don't need to complete the entire math major to demonstrate such background to admissions committees.  If you want to pick between math and EECS, EECS has more relevant coursework, so that is probably advisable, not only because you will have a stronger background in related fields but also because you can get letters of rec from people that CS PhD admissions will know.  Of course it is still possible to get into good PhD programs with a math background (several professors at Berkeley have done this, for example Recht and Wainwright), but it's less common.

Double majoring could also be an option to consider, but it's arguably unnecessary since math classes at Berkeley are typically easy to get into and you could pick and choose relevant classes without declaring math.

---------------------

I wouldn't say for sure, I know several math majors doing interesting research in AI and looking at AI-related Ph.D. Programs

- you're right, but the numbers are far fewer. if OP is trying to maximize his chances then EECS/CS is the way to go with coursework/research in AI ML. You can look at department websites at other institutions, they most, if not all(?) prefer a EECS/CS background

EECS/CS for sure in AI/ML


---------------------


I wouldn't say for sure, I know several math majors doing interesting research in AI and looking at AI-related Ph.D. Programs

If someone is interested in getting into the field of AI/ML, and potentially also applying to a PHD program in the field, is it better to have gone the EECS/CS route, or instead pursue Applied Math, assuming that you took say 170, 188 and 189 (perhaps 127 as well), along with the necessary math classes?

It seems to me that the type of proof oriented and rigorous thinking that is gained from majoring in Math is very useful, and hence I was wondering if it could be looked favorably upon by an admissions committee etc. However, maybe people think the quality/competitiveness of the Math classes is not as good as the EECS/CS classes at Berkeley?

I would be interested in hearing what professors think about this, as well as if past students have had experiences with this dilemma and what they picked and why, or if they have been told stuff about this by profs. If they have preferences, can i get reasons why?
